introduction: Ernesto 'Che' Guevara delivered this reflective speech on August 19, 1960, in Havana, Cuba, just eighteen months after the revolution's triumph, while serving in senior roles in Castro's government. Guevara was uniquely positioned to articulate the revolution's ideological significance: he had been a medical doctor who witnessed poverty and injustice across Latin America, then joined Castro's movement and played a crucial military role in the insurgency's victory. In this speech, he recounts his personal transformation from bourgeois professional to revolutionary, positioning himself as emblematic of the broader social upheaval Cuba was undergoing. Speaking to audiences seeking to understand how revolution transforms consciousness and commitment, Guevara modeled the psychological and ethical shift revolutionaries undergo. The speech was influential across the developing world, where it inspired activists and fighters. It established Guevara's philosophy that revolution required total personal commitment and fundamental reorientation of values, not merely political or military victory.
analysis: Guevara's speech exemplifies Case History framework applied to consciousness transformation and ideological conversion. He introduces himself as the primary character whose journey from doctor to revolutionary embodies the speech's thesis. The 'conflict' section recounts vivid experiences: witnessing colonial exploitation in Guatemala, observing continental poverty and disease, recognizing the insufficiency of medical charity without systemic change. These personal encounters catalyze his transformation; the conflict is both external (social injustice) and internal (growing consciousness that professional detachment is complicity). Guevara broadens the lens by arguing his individual transformation mirrors necessary collective change: revolution isn't merely military seizure of power but fundamental reorientation of human commitment and values. The call to action is philosophical and existential: to become truly revolutionary requires not merely joining a movement but undergoing the same consciousness-raising journey Guevara describes. The framework deviates by emphasizing internal psychological change over external suffering, though lived experience of injustice remains foundational. Students can observe how Case History adapts to ideological contexts, where personal narrative becomes testimony to consciousness-raising. The speech demonstrates that the framework can structure arguments about human transformation, using individual biography to prove that revolution requires and produces new forms of consciousness and commitment.
